page.title: 15Landscape
page.content: Worthlodge Forest is on the road from Worth to Balcombe. It consists of mixed coniferous and deciduous trees. Worthlodge Forest is crossed by public footpaths, tractor tracks and bridleways. Because of the clay soil and not much sunlight there are few flowers, but the ones that are there are Buttercups, Celendines, Foxgloves and Nipperwort. In Spring, Bluebells cover the floor. The forest is covered in fern. The main coniferous trees are Pine, Larch and Norwegian Spruce and the decidious trees are Lime, Oak and Sweet Chestnut. There are wild deer, rabbits and squirrels. The pine is used as timber and the Norwegian Spruces are sold as Christmas trees. The forest belongs to the Trustees of Paddock Hurst. The only buildings were a small pig farm and a run-down farmhouse.
